justification: “We assessed digital health-literacy with four items asking their subjective ability to browse, search and find as well as assess the quality and trustworthiness of digital health-related content. We created these items in accordance with … the HLS EU-Q16.”

“Additionally, we asked participants to rate their political orientation on a continuum (ranging from 1-10): ‘Many people use the terms “left” and “right” when they want to describe different political views…’.”

measured_by: single-item approval rating after each trial
justification: “Participants … filled in two items assessing social norms after each trial. Regarding injunctive norms, we asked participants to rate the following statement: ‘The people I care about in my personal Twitter network approve of me sharing Covid-19-related information…’.”

measured_by: single-item perception of others’ sharing after each trial
justification: “Regarding descriptive norms, the statement read: ‘The people I care about in my personal Twitter network … share Covid-19-related information such as the ones I just saw’.”

measured_by: ratings of positive/negative traits for in-group vs out-group
justification: “In study 3, we assessed inter-group bias on positive and negative traits after each trial… participants rated how well those described their personal Twitter network as well as others with similar or different opinions on COVID-19.”

measured_by: three-item scale adapted from Leach et al. (2008)
justification: “Participants were asked to answer whether they agreed with three statements regarding their in-group-identification post-assessment on a seven-point scale (e.g., ‘I am similar to others who have opinions on COVID-19 similar to mine’, Leach et al. (2008)).”
